paper_title.en: Dielectric relaxation in Yb-doped SrZrO3 O. Kamishima, Y. Abe, T. Ishii, J. Kawamura and T. Hattori
Relaxation Modes of Classical Hopping Protons in Perovskite Structures I Tadao Ishii and Atsushi Ichigozaki
Quasi-Debye response of ion-hopping conduction at lowest frequencies
Incoherent scattering functions of hopping particles in random lattices

description.en: The incoherent scattering functions of hopping particles in random systems are theoretically examined in terms of the relaxation mode theory, focusing on the intermediate scattering function and dynamical structure factor. In the former, we discuss how it correlates with the diffusion coefficients in the small q approximation, which reflect the anomalous behavior of the nondiffusive modes. While in the latter, the non-BPP spin-lattice relaxation is investigated where the mechanism is explained by the contribution of the diffusive and extended nondiffusive relaxation modes.

publication_name.en: JOURNAL OF THE PHYSICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN

paper_title.en: Cluster-Induced Local Distortions and Superionic Transitions of Ionic Conductors Agl and PbF<sub>2</sub>(共著)

publication_name.en: Journal of the Physical Society of Japan

paper_title.en: Theoretical investigation of anomalous diffusion in a random lattice

description.en: The anomalous behavior of the mean square displacement of hopping ions is investigated in a random lattice system by the relaxation mode theory. It is made clear that its short-time behavior, which is linear in time t, is contributed to by the localized nondiffusive modes, and the long-time behavior, also being linear in t, originates from the diffusive mode. In the intermediate time domain, two anomalous regions exist which are universally expressed by [Delta R(t)(2)] approximate to C't(k') + Ct(k), typically with k' approximate to 0 and k approximate to 0.4: the localized nondiffusive modes result in C't(k') dominating the shorter-time region while the extended nondiffusive modes govern the longer-time region of Ct(k). (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Cluster-induced local distortion in ionic conductors - Negative static expansion

description.en: A model theory of the local distortion in the low-temperature phase of superionic conductors is proposed. The model is based on the coupling between an ion-cluster and a static distortion and is investigated in terms of the pair approximation of the cluster variation method. This cluster-induced local distortion drives a first-order phase transition of order-disorder type. The negative and positive local expansions of Cu-Br distance experimentally found for crystal gamma-CuBr are quantitatively discussed by use of the present theory. The results show a good overall agreement with the experiments, implying that the present model is applicable to ionic conductors. (C) 1998 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

Extended X-Ray Absorption Fine Structure Study on Anharmonic Pair Potential in CuBr(共著)
Non-Debye behavior of ion-hopping conduction

description.en: On the basis of the relaxation mode (relaxon) theory, a relaxation function which expresses the time dependence of hopping conduction in a many-ion system on a regular lattice and with a screened Coulomb interaction, is analytically and numerically discussed. It is shown that the hyperbolic and stretched-exponential relaxations determine the non-Debye behavior in the low-temperature, short-time region and in the high-temperature, long-time region, respectively.

publication_name.en: JOURNAL OF THE PHYSICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN

paper_title.en: High-Temperature Expansions for Frenkel-Kontorova Model(共著)
THE PATH PROBABILITY ANSATZ AND MASTER EQUATION

description.en:
A trial is made of a quasi-stochastic approach to the non-equilibrium statistical mechanics on the basis of Kikuchi's path probability ansatz. In a state arbitrarily away from thermal equilibrium, the general Baye's rule is derived in which the transition probability explicitly involves a time-dependent Hamiltonian and particle number.
This newly derived transition probability is utilized to obtain the mesoscopic master equation, and thus, the Fokker-Planck equation which is reinterpreted in terms of a set of canonical coordinates. One of other applications is the production rate of dynamical path entropy, being made up of the internal entropy production rate and absorption rate of free energy out of the environment. The many-particle hoppings are also investigated by the field theoretical approach.

paper_title.en: RELAXATIONAL FRACTONS IN HOPPING CONDUCTION ON FRACTAL LATTICE

description.en: On the basis of the relaxation mode theory, the hopping conduction on fractal lattices is investigated by the direct use of a set of eigenvalues and eigenstates for the relaxational fractions, where the relaxational fraction is a hopping version of the vibrational fraction. The obtained conductivity formula gives us full information over all the frequency and temperature range. Especially at a frequency and temperature range, its frequency-dependence is identical to the result derived by Alenxander and Orbach for fractal and percolation lattices. This scheme of dealing with the relaxational fractions is quite useful for the study of dynamical properties in the hopping conduction: the quasi-elastic light scattering and ultrasonic attenuation are also discussed on the same ground.
